description.content: In this lesson we will practise how to express one's decision to do something. This grammar pattern is used with volitional actions performed by the speaker. We will also learn a related expression used when the speaker performs an action due to arrangements or events outside of his control. The choice between these two expressions to use is determined by whether or not the speaker made a voluntary decision. See the example sentences below for examples.

japanese.content: シャツを買うことにする
シャツをかうことにする
shatsu wo kau koto ni suru

translated.content: I've decided to buy a shirt.

japanese.content: コーラを飲むことにしました
コーラをのむことにしました
ko-ra wo nomu koto ni shimashita
テレビを見ないことにした
テレビをみないことにした
terebi wo minai koto ni sita

translated.content: I decided not to watch TV.

japanese.content: 漫画をよまないことにした
まんがをよまないことにした
manga wo yomanai koto ni sita

translated.content: I decided not to read comics.

japanese.content: 日本で英語を教えることになりました。
にほんでえいごをおしえることになりました。
nihon de eigo wo osieru koto ni narimasita

translated.content: It's been decided that I'll teach English in Japan.

japanese.content: 京都に引っ越すことになった。
きょうとにひっこすことになった。
kyoto ni hikkosu koto ni natta

translated.content: It's been arranged that I'll move to Kyoto.

japanese.content: 来月休まないことになりました。
らいげつやすまないことになりました。
raigetu yasumanai koto ni narimasita

translated.content: It's been decided that I won't go on vacation next month.

japanese.content: 来年東京に行かないことになった。
らいねんとうきょうにいかないことになった。
rainen toukyou ni ikanai koto ni natta

translated.content: It's been decided that I won't go to Tokyo next year.

u.b: Grammar Point 1: Volitional decisions to perform actions

grammar_points.p: This grammar pattern is used when the speaker makes a volitional decision to do something. By adding ことにする to a subordinate clause that ends with a verb in the plain, non-past form the speaker indicates that he has made a decision to perform the action described in the clause.
映画を見ることにしました。 "I decided to watch a movie."
京都に行くことにした。 "I decided to go to Kyoto."
Negating the verb indicates that the speaker has decided not to perform the action.
明日学校に行かないことにした。 "I decided not to go to school tomorrow."
その本を買わないことにしました。 "I decided not to buy that book."
Note that this grammar pattern can only be used when the subordinate clause describes a volitional action by the speaker, so verbs and clauses that do not fit this restriction are not possible.

u.b: Grammar Point 2: Events that occur irregardless of the speaker's volition

grammar_points.p: While the previous grammar pattern is used for volitional decisions made by the speaker, the related expression ことになる is used for actions that happen because of something outside of the speaker's control. The nuance is that events have unfolded irregardless of the speaker's volition. The most common use of this expression is to show the result of a decision or arrangement made by an unspecified agent.
東京に転勤することになりました。 "It has been decided that I will transfer to Tokyo."
来年イギリスを留学することになった。 "It has been arranged that I will study abroad in England next year."
Because this form expresses the idea that the action occurred irregardless of the speaker's volition, it is also used like the expressions 'turn out' or 'come about' in English.
姉と喧嘩することになった。 "I ended up fighting with my older sister."
